Becky, all - 

It is interesting that when offering a "mounted" sword of th=
is quality that people will want to pay less than if you would break it apa=
rt and sell the blade and fittings seperately. Not quite sure what that is =
but I've more than a few times have (as most of us have) sold off fittings =
seperately from the sword. (Unless, I should add, the sword is nicely mount=
ed in a relatively complete and intact koshirae.) 

As for a sword like thi=
s being worth much more after being "appraised, documented or auctioned," o=
ne has to realize that these directions take money to do these things. I'm =
not sure what a reliable appraiser would charge today but for a stateside "=
paper" you would pay around $250; to send a sword to Japan it might run $1,=
200 (Tokubetsu Hozon) after you are finished with shipping and fees and reg=
istrations. Auction houses charge seller fees and catalogue fees. Nothing c=
omes cheap! 

Just rattling on a bit...

Ron
STL

  From: BECKY WALLACE

  Sent: S=
aturday, January 06, 2007 4:36 PM
  Subject: [nihontostudy] Becky's Sword

=

  I'd like to thank everyone who has been helping me with Japanese Sword i=
nfo lately. We did go to the Gun show here in Dallas today. Sold the WWII J=
apanese rifle we had - it was not a very good piece and I'm glad to have it=
 out of the closet. Had several people look at the sword. The blade, as has=
 been pointed out by some of you, was not signed and it has one nick that i=
s slightly too big to be polished out, which detracts considerably from the=
 value. There was concurance that this sword was made in the 1600s and is a=
 Washika (spelling) the shoter sword. Everyone liked the tsuba, end cap and=
 collar. I got offered about $500 for the tsuba and $100 each for the colla=
r and end cap, but just $300 for the whole thing! The conclusion I came to =
was that a gun show was really more like a giant pawn shop than the place t=
o really get a fair assessment of value, but it was very interesting, I ran=
 into at least 3 of my co-workiers from Lockheed who had booths, and I did =
come
  away knowing a few things: 1. the sword is old and really not in bad=
 shape - I can continue to use it in the event of an intruder and could pro=
bably take one out with it - I'm not a handgun fan :-) 2. If I really had i=
t appraised, documented, or auctioned, I'd get $1500 or so for it, 3. I lik=
e it more than that so will be keeping it for the forseeable future. I'll p=
robably drop out of this group in a few weeks having accomplished my missio=
n, but thanks for the education. I can sure see how this could become a ver=
y interesting hobby.

  Becky
